On 12/8/05, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
>
> On 12/=
7/05, viveksaxena1975 <viveks@...> wrote:
> > I havnt yet started us=
ing Junit, I am just considering.
> > I need to develop test suite based on=
 Unix and I dont want to use IDE.
> > is that OK ?
>
> Yes.
>
> Further tha=
n that, I recommend it. Where I work, we always perform
> builds (and the r=
unning of their JUnit tests) for deployment to our
> application servers on=
 dedicated build machines. We never perform
> deployment builds on a develo=
per's workstation; far too many unknowns
> and differences between develope=
rs and what they do to their machines.


The two are not mutually exclusive=
.

Everybody around me uses an IDE and while they are doing development, th=
ey
build everything inside the IDE and when they are ready to check in, the=
y
move to the shell/command prompt and build with ant to make sure they are=

not breaking anything.

I *strongly* recommend using an IDE, and not just =
for JUnit.  Maybe you
think you are productive with your current text edito=
r (emacs, vi, TextEdit,
etc...) but I guarantee that your productivity will=
 shoot up with an IDE.

--
C=E9dric
